title: 04. Augustus' Moral Legislation
description: Augustus’ use of moral laws to promote traditional values, marriage, and childbirth while regulating elite behaviour.

questions.question: What moral problems did Augustus believe were particularly common among the Roman upper classes?
options: Adultery, casual marriage, avoidance of child-rearing, and excessive luxury
Military indiscipline and refusal to serve in the legions
Religious neglect and hostility to traditional gods
Provincial rebellion and tax evasion

questions.question: Why might Augustus’ promotion of traditional morality appear hypocritical to contemporaries?
options: He openly rejected Roman religion
His own early behaviour and family life conflicted with his moral ideals
He never married and had no children
He refused to enforce his laws on elites

questions.question: Which aspect of Augustus’ family life most clearly conflicted with his later moral legislation?
options: His refusal to acknowledge his heirs
His daughter's notorious sexual behaviour
His exile of political rivals
His adoption of Tiberius

questions.question: What does Augustus’ treatment of Julia suggest about his commitment to moral legislation?
options: He ignored the law when family was involved
He enforced the law even at great personal cost
He repealed the law to protect her
He publicly defended her actions

questions.question: How did Augustus attempt to encourage population growth among Roman citizens?
options: By granting land to veterans only
By encouraging immigration
By rewarding marriage and childbirth through legislation
By abolishing inheritance laws

questions.question: What was Augustus’ stated concern regarding the Roman population?
options: That Romans were becoming too wealthy
That Roman stock would be diluted by foreign or servile blood
That the army was shrinking
That women held too much power

questions.question: What was the main purpose of the Lex Julia de ambitu (18 BCE)?
options: To punish adultery
To regulate marriage across classes
To penalise electoral bribery
To restrict luxury spending

questions.question: What did the Lex Julia de maritandis ordinibus aim to achieve?
options: The abolition of marriage among elites
Encouragement of marriage within social classes and punishment of celibacy
Greater political rights for women
Legalisation of adultery

questions.question: Which incentive was used by the Lex Papia Poppaea (9 CE)?
options: Reduced military service
Political and legal advantages for parents of many children
Abolition of property taxes
Guaranteed public office

questions.question: What irony is associated with the passing of the Lex Papia Poppaea?
options: It was proposed by married consuls
It failed immediately
It was passed by two unmarried consuls
It repealed earlier laws
